p: Identified as one of the most abundant nonnative fishes in Florida, Belonesox belizanus is native to waters (temperature is 25–37 °C) in Mexico and Central America, and was introduced into a ditch in south Florida in the late 1950s [ 37, 38, 39, 40, 41, 42, 43]. It is a specialist predator, feeding on small fishes using a feeding mechanism that is well designed for piscivory. This piscivore is capable of achieving a large gape with its elongated premaxillae and mandibles lined with large teeth [ 44, 45, 46]. The ability of pike killifish to independently rotate its premaxilla posterodorsally, facilitated by the premaxillomandibular ligament and a twisting maxilla, further enhances gape formation [ 45].
